awd_titl_txt: Addressing Ubiquitous STEM Gender Performance Differences
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a wide reaching project that combines strands of a number of NSF priorities and earlier NSF-supported projects, including "Writing to Learn," WIDER (institutional transformation), INCLUDES (broadening participation), Cyber learning, and Big Data Analytics. Using big data analytics, it has been quantitatively established that female students taking introductory STEM lecture courses at 10 major public research universities show evidence of stereotype threat, which lowers their course performance by 5% to 10% and discourages some from continuing as STEM majors. The goal of the project is to continue to refine and employ a digital mentoring/ treatment tool that has undergone pilot stage testing to deliver up to three types of treatments to countervail the presence of stereotype threat. This tool has the potential to be customized for each student. It was developed with early stage support from an earlier NSF/ DUE grant. This tool will use a writing-to-learn tool being developed under an NSF/IUSE grant. The writing tool is building a comprehensive writing system, combining peer review tools with a natural language processing toolkit designed to provide actionable information about student responses to the digital mentoring tool. This project is expected to have a substantial direct impact on female STEM students and has good prospects for encouraging more of them to remain in STEM as their primary college major. If the tool proves to be effective in eliminating gender performance differences in STEM courses, it is likely to be employed in a growing number of other research universities, thereby multiplying its impact. 

The project itself will work with 5,000 distinct undergraduate women in a randomized treatment design to test the efficacy of basic treatment and to test the improved efficacy of individualizing the treatment for each student. Because all of the interactions with students will take place through the digital mentoring/ treatment tool framework, the project will have complete control over what each student experiences, along with a comprehensive "treatment record" of what each student encountered and did within the system, including the writing they did in response to the intervention prompts. The ability to control and record personalized treatment for every individual allows the treatment to be assessed through randomized trials. This approach has been the key to the development of sequential multiple assignment randomized trials in digital health coaching, for example.

por.por_cntn:
This project used ECoach, an innovative computer-tailored communication system to test the efficacy of social psychological interventions on long-standing outcome inequities in large foundational STEM courses. These tests were conducted across a range of STEM disciplines over multiple semesters, with thousands of students participating. In addition to electronic delivery of these interventions at scale, we also replicated on-paper versions of these interventions in courses enrolling more than 500 students. 

When this project began, there was significant enthusiasm about the application of social psychology interventions like values affirmation as a potentially scalable approach to reducing inequitable outcomes in large foundational science courses. Since that time, our research and that of several other groups have made clear the essential 'fragility' of these interventions. To have a chance at efficacy, they must be not only applied with care, they must be thoughtfully contextualized. We are forced to conclude that they do not provide a simple solution to a widespread and persistent problem. 

This conclusion has helped to turn the attention of the community in a new direction, toward a recognition that the elimination of exclusionary inequities will require structural change in foundational STEM courses. Experiments with these structural changes have now begun, with shifts toward active learning, more authentic assessment, mastery assessment, and more.

The results of this work have been shared with the broader STEM education community through a wide variety of channels. These include formal publication and presentations at a variety of conferences. Especially important connections for dissemination have been provided by several multi-institutional collaborations. 

The Sloan Equity and Inclusion in STEM Introductory Courses (or SEISMIC) project has brought together STEM education researchers and practioners from ten major public research universities enrolling more than 600,000 students since its founding in 2019. Multiple SEISMIC partner institutions utilize ECoach, so that results from its applications, including the investigations supported by this grant, are frequently shared across this collaboration. 

We have also had considerable success in disseminating this work through administrative collaborations like the Undergraduate Education at Research Universities (or UERU) consortium and the Big Ten Academic Alliance. These gatherings of high level higher education administrators provide consistent and direct access to individuals with influence over all of the STEM teaching on their campuses, a reach much greater than any individual faculty member might provide. 

The ultimate goal of this grant was to explore ways to address ubiquitous gendered performance differences in foundational STEM courses. We have concluded that social psychological interventions like values affirmation are unlikely to eliminate these inequities. This conclusion leads us to turn our attention to the structures within these courses which act to generate these gendered performance differences, and that work is now underway.
